 RUSSIAN FEDERATION ENTERPRISE RESTRUCTURING SERVICES PROJECT TECHNICAL ANNEX 1. INTRODUCTION 1.1 The Government of Russia (GOR) is committed to stabilizing and restructuring the national economy. This commitment is reflected, inter alia, in the ongoing program of macro-economic and structural reforms supported under the new Bank Group Country Assistance Strategy. With the achievement of a relatively stable macro-economic environment, the focus of the reforms is shifting towards structural adjustment of the economy to market conditions which will ultimately help to re-start the economic growth. 1.2 This re-start requires foremostly higher mobility of all factors of production, which are heavily concentrated in the organized enterprise sector, with its some 25,000 medium and large enterprises. This makes enterprise reform a high priority. 1.3 Enterprise reform of such a scope lacks several key ingredients. First, the gap in the management skills between the Russian managers and their counterparts from the West, and even from Eastern Europe, remains substantial. Second, the absence of the relevant market infrastructure constrains purchases of these skills to bridge this gap. Third, enterprises, privatized with no capital input under mass privatization, have no means to cover the inherent costs of restructuring. In its tum, slow progress in restructuring impedes enterprises' access to financial markets and further deepens the aforementioned financial and managerial gaps. 1.4 While some enterprises have started to search for restructuring expertise in the market, the majority continues to adjust through accumulation of arrears to state, labor and suppliers. Responding to the need of catalyzing restructuring process, the GOR has developed an Enterprise Reform Strategy to accelerate enterprise reform at micro-level. The proposed Project will support further elaboration and implementation of the Strategy as it will provide a broad range of corporate advisory services to help enterprises restore their economic viability and gain access to market sources of enterprise finance. The project would also broaden the institutional base of restructuring by involving in this process enterprises, banks, potential investors, local consultants, and develop a substantial number of prototype restructuring cases to help the GOR further elaborate its Enterprise Reform Strategy.
 - 2 - 2. SECTORAL CONTEXT A. OUTPUT DECLINE AND RESTRUCTURING 2.1 Russian industry2 has faced large adverse shocks since the breakup of the Soviet Union, both on the demand and the supply sides. Federal and local government transfers, i.e. explicit subsidies and cheap credits, have dropped significantly in real terms since 1992, imposing increasingly hard budget constrains on the firms. As a result, the industrial output has fallen dramatically. As of September 1996, it was roughly 40% of the 1990 level. Light industries, metallurgy, machine-building, chemicals, and petro-chemicals sub-sectors have experienced the deepest declines. Sub-sectoral variations in output performance are reflected in regional differences. The Central region and North Caucuses as well as the largest cities, Moscow and St.-Petersburg, were among the most affected. 2.2 Enterprise adjustment was slow and so far mainly focused on reductions in working hours, wages, and, to a much lesser extent, employment itself. While reduction of employment is starting to accelerate gradually, in relation to the decline in output, firms still retain excess labor. Directors still tend to preserve intact their labor force (and production) as indicated in a recent survey3 in which 46% of directors stated this as their achievement. Employment bias is reinforced by the fact that unemployment benefits present an inadequate fall-back option for dismissed workers, and firms tend to retain them but adjust the hours worked and the monetary compensation. Firms also lack liquidity to provide separation packages. 2.3 Updating the product mix and the development of production were listed as the major achievements by only 10% of the directors. Very few of them listed as major achievements development of new technology, increased competitiveness, improvement of quality, reorganization, entering new markets, change of the production profile and new investment. This suggests that managers lack skills to address these areas. Directors cited as main obstacles taxation, cost increases for production inputs, customers' payment problems, low demand on the domestic market, obsolete equipment and technology. In the short-term, they intend to respond to these problems through one or several of the following: cost- reduction, price increase, advertisement, employment reductions, sale or lease of assets. In the longer term, their focus will be on improving product quality, changing distribution and sales systems, attracting foreign investors/partners, improving technology, reorganizing, changing their management systems. B. ENTERPRISE FINANCE 2.4 Government Transfers. In 1994, some 25% of the enterprises still received some form of subsidy from the GOR, but the transfers have been declining in real terms, mostly been directed towards very large firms, and related to a combination of employment-stabilizing objectives and compensatory finance for the provision of social services. In summary, while not all Russian enterprises face a full hard budget constraint as yet, the typical medium to large enterprises are facing serious budget constraints and have incentives to restructure. 2.5 Transacting Purchases and Sales. Working capital finance has become increasingly difficult to obtain and severe payment problems have arisen. Enterprises, even efficient ones, have to transact their sales through barter or offsets, often involving up to 10 intermediaries in a complex circle of barter-based exchange, costing up to 10 percent of sales. Retail sales and exports are the main sources of ready cash. Hence, there is little that enterprises can do, apart from better inventory management and choosing final products that can be sold for cash. Payment problems of the GOR itself exacerbate this situation and have contributed to the emergence of an illiquid and expensive system of tax offsets and bills of exchange. Last, the banks are slow in making payments, partly because of an inadequate payment system infrastructure and technology and partly because they make money on the float. 2.6 Financial Markets. Commercial lending activity is severely suppressed, as banks are presently more interested in acquiring equities in blue chip companies and in investing in highly profitable treasury bills and notes (GKOs and OFZs). The latter has created a serious crowding out issue for the private sector. Although the interest rates on treasury bills and notes are expected to come down if the recent sharp drop in inflation is sustained, the pace at which this will take place is uncertain. Banks are also hesitant to expand lending activities to the enterprise sector because the non-performing portion on their existing loan portfolios has increased as stabilization has taken hold, pointing to potential liquidity problems and the risk of bank failures. Only few banks are systematically looking for lending opportunities to enterprises. The domestic capital market for primary issues of equity and bonds is thin, issues are impeded by lack of reliable accounts and problems with disclosure of company information, and access to international financial markets is limited to a few natural resources exporters. 2.7 In order to obtain finance for working capital and investment, enterprises need either to generate internal cash or to obtain access to financial markets. Restructuring of their businesses and achieving sustainable performance is a key precondition for both. C. CORPORATE OWNERSHIP AND GOVERNANCE4 2.8 Corporate Ownership. Privatized firms are largely owned by insiders. About 60% of surveyed companies were majority-owned by rank-and-file employees. However, workers are exerting little, if any, influence over management, due to insufficient representation, lack of interest in corporate governance and in monitoring their shareholdings. Managers own on average 17% of their company's stock, a higher percentage than indicated in an earlier survey. This increase is being achieved by several mechanisms, including purchase through investment tenders and cash auctions, stock buybacks, and dilutive share issues. The state is no longer a significant shareholder in most of the privatized companies, holding on average about 9 percent of outstanding stock (as of end- 1995). 2.9 Private outside ownership has grown from 22 % at the end of 1993 to 31% at the end of 1995. The pattern of outsider share ownership of Russian privatized enterprises is uneven, with outsiders heavily concentrated in a few companies. A presidential decree of end-1993 and the 1996 Law on Joint Stock Companies mandate all companies with more than 1000 shareholders to use cumulative voting for the election of board of directors. D. ENTERPRISE DEMAND FOR RESTRUCTURING SERVICES 2.14 Priority areas in which consultants presently are and in the future are expected to be engaged by the surveyed enterprises are taxation (25% of enterprises), technical and managerial training (19%), organizing subsidiaries and departments (18%), enterprise valuation, share issue (18%), distribution channels (16%), advertisement (16%), foreign partner search (17%), legal services (16%), capital investments (16%), MIS (15%), audit and revisions (12%), packaging (13%), and business plans (15%). Enterprises have specific views on what types of organizations rendering consulting services they would entrust with projects in a number of specific areas, particularly when comparing Russian and foreign consulting firms. Russian consulting firms are seen to have a significant advantage in the areas of financial matters and accounting (29% of surveyed enterprises versus 8% of surveyed enterprises, respectively), legal services (29% vs 3%), relations with state bodies and main shareholders (19% vs 3%), and executive search and training (20% vs 13%). Foreign consultants come out ahead in the areas of distribution technology (19% vs 13%), foreign economic activities (31% vs 11%), and engineering services and design (17% vs 11%). Russian and foreign firms were more or less even in the areas of production management, marketing and sales, and general enterprise management. 2.15 This structure of enterprise demand indicates that the TA needs of enterprises are complex and diverse. Both western patterns of developing marketing, engineering, and production management and local knowledge of the Russian institutional, accounting, taxation, and legal context must be brought to bear. This will be addressed through a number of project approaches and activities, including: (i) project promotion explaining the benefits and risks of engaging consultants; (ii) competitive procurement of good quality consultants; (iii) teaming up foreign and local consultants in order to ensure adequate skills mix for provision of relevant advisory services; (iv) selecting restructuring Sub-Projects which are oriented towards delivery of tangible operational and financial benefits to BEs. E. SUPPLY OF RESTRUCTURING SERVICES: GENERAL OVERVIEW 2.16 The young consulting industry in Russia is represented by foreign and local firms, with almost no joint-ventures. The leading international companies started to operate in Russia from 1990. Until recently they dominated the market serving mainly "high-end of the market" clients. 2.17 Following the gradually growing demand of newly privatized enterprises for professional services, medium-size foreign consulting firms and local consulting companies have started to emerge in the market. Mainly, they are providing auditing services, gradually complementing them with numerous other services as an ad hoc response to their clients' needs (e.g. clarifying the legal status and the property rights, navigating firms through rapidly changing legislation, assisting with some corrective actions and -- a popular service -- preparing "business plans" perceived by clients as bankable). 2.18 Several dozen medium-size foreign and Russian consulting firms, together with the leading world consulting firms account for about 70 percent of the total consulting market in Russia, according
 - 6 - to the following ranking: (a) the "big six"; (b) 20-50 medium-size foreign-owned consulting firms; (c) 20-30 medium-to large-size (over 50 employees) locally-owned consulting firms; (d) unidentified number (over a thousand) of small firms and individuals. 2.19 The "big six" are most visible in the market because (i) they have easier access to work with international companies in Russia, leading banks, and the large export-oriented enterprises, i.e. the clients interested in the consultants "brand name"; (ii) they win a substantial share of the donor-funded contracts due to the lack of the domestic firms' prior experience to qualify under the international procurement standards and resources to handle large-scope contracts. 2.20 Small and medium-size foreign consulting firms as a rule combine provision of general management consulting services with auditing. Also, a large portion of their activities focus on corporate finance, financial brokerage and search of an external strategic partner/investor. 2.21 There is a structural mismatch between the enterprise demand for professional services for restructuring and the market supply. Large foreign consulting firms, able to cover all or many areas of enterprises' needs, are not affordable to them, especially if the cost of their services is compared with the production cost structure of a typical enterprise. Local firms have lower costs and better familiarity with the Russian institutional context. However, the quality of their advice is uneven across the areas of expertise and is difficult to verify. As a result, enterprises either do not hire consultants even if they need them, or use their services in a piecemeal fashion, when advice is provided in isolation from the broad picture of an enterprise's performance, and does not receive adequate follow ups. Hence, enterprises do not reap full benefits from services, and are further discouraged from their systematic use. The proposed project will address the mismatch between the demand and the supply by coaching enterprises through restructuring process, teaming up foreign and local consultants, focusing enterprise restructuring efforts on priority areas, and encouraging consistent implementation of the restructuring plans. LESSONS OF EXPERIENCE 3.1 The Russian enterprise sector shares with other economies in transition features which influence enterprise restructuring, such as the lack of enabling environment, weak market infrastructure for restructuring and the absence of the market-oriented managerial skills. Experience of the Bank and of bilaterally funded projects in Eastern Europe and Russia indicate several lessons presented below. 3.2 The Bank has assisted private enterprise restructuring in transitional economies almost exclusively through "traditional financial intermediary lending".6 The Bank OED study attributes the mixed success of such lending to, inter alia, the lack of attention to (i) the institutional arrangements required for efficient decision-making of both the enterprises and the financial intermediaries; and (ii) the technological, managerial, financial and labor needs of enterprises associated with mass privatization. 3.3 The ongoing First Private Sector Development Project in the Republic of Moldova (Ln 14555- MD), and the Enterprise and Financial Sector Assistance Project in Lithuania (Ln 3866-LT) reinforce the lines of credit to enterprises with restructuring TA provided on a partially cost-recovered basis. These two projects have demonstrated so far that: (i) cost-sharing by participating enterprises improves their incentives to restructure, introduces their demand-driven self-selection, and, contributes to higher rate of successful turnarounds; (ii) local consultants' involvement facilitates transfer of skills to local private sector and contributes to the development of the infant consulting industry. 3.4 It may be argued that due to the lack of the market information about the value of consulting services, there may be little demand for the TA at-fll cost-recovery. The Private Investment and Export Project in Bulgaria (Ln 3631 --BG), under which the Government on-lends Bank funds for TA to PFIs, suggests the existence of effective demand from private sector in transition economies to borrow for TA. 3.5 The project incorporates also the lessons of restructuring programs in Russia, which fall into two categories. First, in 1994-96 under the EU/TACIS, USAID and EBRD-funded programs, 54 enterprises were restructured on a grant basis, and, second, under the Privatization Implementation Assistance Loan (PIAL, Ln 3546-RU), 8 pilot restructuring cases are being funded on a loan basis since August, 1996. Another 30 enterprises are in the pipeline for loan-based TA under the proposed Project. 3.6 The loan-based pilots have shown so far that (i) enterprises are willing to borrow for TA when they are ensured of being coached through the restructuring process; (ii) they have strong preference for a combination of domestic and foreign skills; (iii) a typical restructuring proposal combines elements of diagnostics with intensive follow-ups in one or several of the following areas: (a) financial management and cost reduction; (b) marketing and distribution technology; (c) organizational restructuring; (d) personnel training. The evaluation indicates that the sample benefited from the TA, though the benefits vary by sub-sectors and by types of restructuring. Net financial gains, exceeding 5-8 times the cost of the TA input and obtained within 2-6 months after the completion of a sub-project, were observed in about 31% of the cases, mainly at enterprises in sub-sectors with a short business cycle, and where "quick-fix" adjustments (financial, MIS, building marketing units) were carried out. Sustainability of these benefits depends, ceteris paribus, on the enterprise's internalization of the new business practices. About 38% of the sample enterprises undertook organizational, personnel management and comprehensive marketing (developing new markets and identification new products) restructuring, with longer on-site presence of consultants and a longer gestation period. This sub-sample has mainly increased its capacity utilization and incremental sales growth (exceeding the cost of the TA input by 135% on average). The managers of this sub-sample confirmed that their strategic vision of the company's development as well as the intrinsic quality of the organization have improved, which, in their view, would translate in net financial gains in about 15-18 months after the end of the assignment. However, it may be argued, that longer on-site presence of consultants helps the recipient to internalize the new business practices, and, hence, the benefits would be more sustainable. In about 30% of the remaining cases, the managers were either uncertain about the achieved results, or were concerned that they may not be able to sustain the achieved level of performance after consultants' departure, and hence would consider inviting them for follow-ups. The main objective is to develop a sustainable capacity in the Russian private sector for market-based restructuring and, thus, promote enterprise reform in Russia, a process presently constrained by a number of market failures and barriers as well as institutional constraints as described below (paragraph 4.2). The project has three specific objectives: (i) to help about 250 private enterprises improve their operational/financial performance, in general, and become bankable, in particular; (ii) to strengthen the local consulting industry in this process and equip it to meet the expected growing enterprise demand for business advisory services; and (iii) to broaden the institutional base of the restructuring process and provide incentives to the key market agents, i.e. enterprise managers, consultants, banks, institutional investors to initiate and drive the restructuring process. 4.2 Proiect Rationale rests on the need to promote enterprise reform at large, which is progressing so far slowly due to the market failures and barriers to restructuring, as well as institutional constraints, including: (a) Enterprises willing to restructure lack skills to do so and need to buy them in the market. Asymmetry of information about the value of consulting services among the potential users (enterprises) and the potential providers (consultants) hinders transactions between the parties. While there is factual evidence of such transactions, they happen mainly when buyers have means to assess the value of the services, often with the help of an experienced outside owner. The project will reduce the asymmetry by introducing an intermediary, the Russian Privatization Center (RPC), to coach enterprises through selection and managing consultants. RPC will play this role temporarily and will work with enterprises, banks, consultants to increase their role in the implementation, so that the informational constraints in the market are gradually reduced. (b) The quality of local consulting services is falling short of enterprises' needs due to a lack of know-how and capacity. The project will support the infant industry by facilitating know-how transfer from foreign to local consultants through their teaming up under the project. An increased supply of efficient local consulting services, affordable to enterprises at large, would strengthen the institutional base of the restructuring process. (c) Investments in enterprise sector are hindered, inter alia, by the lack of market information about the value of privatized companies. Demand-driven, loan-based TA implies self-selection of the BEs. Some eligible enterprises may be not committed to restructuring, some others may not pass the screening, yet others may fail to obtain a securing instrument for their Sub-Loans. Finally, the degree of success in restructuring will vary among the BEs. In this process, direct and indirect signals will be sent to the market about the value of, and the risks of lending to, over 1,000 eligible enterprises. (d) The lack of enterprise financing to cover restructuring costs is another clear barrier to enterprise restructuring and, hence, productive growth. Such financing is not available in the market because (i) banks do not lend for technical assistance, and (ii) new
 - 14 - institutional owners (investment companies and funds) have limited resources and can work with only a small number of enterprises. The project will provide loan-based financial support to BEs. Partial guarantees from the BEs' banks or institutional shareholders will enhance this support and will help develop new institutional and financial relationship for the ongoing market-based restructuring process. (e) The GOR is lacking a comprehensive enterprise reform strategy. The project will help the GOR to test various specific approaches to enterprise restructuring and, hence, will enhance the GOR understanding of the incentive framework conducive to enterprise restructuring and will contribute to the Enterprise Reform Strategy, currently being developed by the MOE. The market failures and barriers for the broad-based restructuring, described in paragraph 4.2 (i.e. the underdeveloped effective enterprise demand for professional consulting services, the lack of quality supply response of the infant local consulting industry and the absence of financing available to enterprises to cover the cost of external expertise required for restructuring) justify public intervention in the form of a temporary initial financial support by the GOR sector to purchase skills, services and training from private providers. Developing publicly supported facilities to assist a large enterprise population to restructure, in an environment with a nascent restructuring infrastructure, has been common since 1960s in many countries (e.g., India, Indonesia,
 - 19 - Kenya, Argentina); and in virtually all East-European transitional economies. Public support of private enterprise restructuring has also been provided in selected OECD countries in the 1970s, when enterprises had to adjust on a mass scale to the new level of energy prices and, hence, to changes in the cost of input and output. In Russia, presently, the state intervention is justified due to (i) the scope and speed of restructuring required to re-start the economic growth; and (ii) the rudimentary market infrastructure to support this process. Assistance under the proposed ERSP will be loan-based and will be less concessional than in many other countries. 4.22 Cost-effectiveness. BENEFITS 6.1 The project will help to implement some 250 restructuring Sub-Projects, targeting tangible operational and/or financial improvements, which will generally (a) strengthen the medium-term viability of the BE; (b) transfer to the BEs the skills of how to work with and use consulting services successfully, which will serve them well for the future and (c) transfer market operation skills to managers and staff in the specific context of their enterprise, which will maximize skill absorption. 6.2 All good quality Sub-Projects of eligible enterprises would be considered for funding under the project. The project will not target only short-term tangible benefits. This may inappropriately rule out significant number of enterprises, especially in sub-sectors with longer business cycle, restructuring of which can bring net financial gains only in 15-18 months after the completion of a Sub-Project. The main benefits for enterprises should be derived from internalizing sound business strategies and practices rather than from targeting "quick-fix" improvements which may not be sustainable in the longer term, as demonstrated by the lessons learned (paragraph 3.7). 6.3 The project would give, ceteris paribus, some priority to Sub-Projects which help enterprises to meet the indicative targets of the GOR Enterprise Reform Strategy, i.e. to (i) improve the enterprises accounting and financial management systems; (ii) introduce the MIS and help the BEs to decrease the share of barter in the overall turnover; (iii) develop new markets and new relationship with customers; (iv) open avenues of access to new capital investment. These changes, if supported by appropriate assistance in internalizing their mechanisms (e.g. by envisaging personnel management training in the Sub-Projects), tend to translate into net financial gains, 5-8 times exceeding the cost of the TA input, within a period of 6-12 months, i.e. faster than, for example, organizational restructuring and developing new production lines. 6.4 Besides the direct benefits to the BEs, there are indirect demonstration benefits which can accrue to a much broader enterprise audience as well as to the enterprise corporate owners and potential investors. The project targets these benefits through a systematic analysis and broad dissemination of the restructuring experience gained through the sub-projects. Surveys demonstrate that enterprise managers look to the experience of other enterprises when undertaking reform and considering to hire consultants. 6.5 Another benefit of the project is that it boosts both the demand for business advisory services in Russia and the quality supply of them. The latter would be ensured by providing Russian consultants with opportunities to participate in restructuring projects with international firms, and to gain the experience, skill, clientele, and references needed to begin to effectively serve the huge Russian enterprise sector. The project design, while staying within the Bank's procurement guidelines, encourages enterprises and consulting firms to interact with each other during Sub-Project preparation and contracting, in as much a market approximating manner as feasible.

RISKS 6.6 The project faces macro-economic and institutional risks: a reversal of the recently achieved stabilization and the inherent unpredictability of the Russian business regulatory environment may exacerbate the difficulties that the enterprise sector faces, making it more difficult to undertake successful restructuring. The project would suffer in several ways: first, demand would likely drop off; second, successful implementation of sub-projects under way could be jeopardized; and third, most importantly, the improvements under Sub-Projects may not be sustainable, thus putting the firm-level benefits as well as Sub-Loan repayment at risk. The project cannot address this risk other than by slowing down implementation or scaling back its scope, if necessary, and must therefore rely on the stabilization policies of the Government, supported by policy lending from the Bank and the IMF. 6.7 The project also faces the risk, that even under favorable macro-economic conditions, the intended sub-project benefits are either not achieved or are not sustainable, because of factors which are not, or only partially under the control of the project and yet have a strong impact on enterprise performance, e.g. ownership changes, corporate governance practices, corporate control behavior. The project addresses this risk in two ways. First, enterprises have a strong self-interest to achieve and sustain project benefits because of their financial exposure, both in terms of co-financing the restructuring services, and with respect to their debt service obligation vis-A-vis the MOF. Second, sub- projects have to be endorsed not only by management, but also by the enterprise board, ensuring broad commitment to the sub-project, at least at entry. 6.8 The project further faces a portfolio risk: by definition, the participating enterprises will generally have significant problems and could be a bad credit risk. Conceptually, the project cannot eliminate this as it explicitly targets enterprises in need of restructuring. The project attempts, however, to mitigate this risk by: (i) assigning great weight to turnaround potential when evaluating sub-projects; and (ii) requiring that, as a rule, a bank guarantee be provided for 50% of the Sub-Loan amount. 6.9 Although demand has been tested (paragraph 4.8) and confirmed, it is possible, that the private sector response to the project is inadequate. This risk is associated mainly with two factors: (i) the trends in the interest market rates, determining the attractiveness of the Project financial terms and conditions; and (ii) the failure on the part of some or many enterprises to comply with the necessity to cover a part of the Sub-Projects' costs. The project addresses this risk in several ways: (i) the project fills a market gap and its product is currently not available in the market place; (ii) project implementation will be accompanied by a promotion campaign; and (iii) the project is engaging shareholders, banks, and consulting companies to identify suitable enterprises and generate Sub-Projects. Finally, the project is calibrated very conservatively and aims to provide support to only about 25% of enterprises of those, which are expected to be interested and eligible to participate. 6.10 The project requires significant project management and administration expertise and collaboration among various private sector participants. The project addresses this implementation risk in the following ways: (i) the implementing agency, the RPC, has a multi-year track record of managing donor financed projects in privatization and enterprise reform, and will further strengthen its capacity under the envisaged project implementation arrangements; (ii) project promotion will help the private sector parties to better understand the project; and (iii) close monitoring of the RPC/LPC would ensure timely practical assistance to the private sector parties involved.

The Russian Federation (RF) in cooperation with the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (hereinafter The World Bank) has prepared an Enterprise Restructuring Services Project (ERSP) to be supported by the Bank Loan. The project will support restructuring of some 250-300 medium and large privatized Russian enterprises which would borrow funds from the Ministry of Finance to hire specialized consulting services in enterprise restructuring. The Russian Privatization Center (RPC), the designated Project Implementation Agency will manage the project implementation in collaboration with the Ministry of Economy and the Ministry of Finance. 2. The main Project objective is to develop a sustainable capacity in the Russian private sector for market-based restructuring. In line with this, the project has three specific objectives: (i) to help about 250 private enterprises improve their operational/financial performance, in general, and become bankable, in particular; (ii) to strengthen the local consulting industry in this process and equip it to meet the expected growing enterprise demand for restructuring advisory services; and (iii) to broaden the institutional base of the restructuring process by providing incentives to the key market agents, i.e. enterprise managers, consultants, banks, institutional investors to initiate and drive the restructuring process. The project will have one core and two supplementary components. 3. The core, Restructuring Services component will provide direct lending from the MOF to private enterprises to finance the consultancies which will help enterprises to reveal their viable core of business, improve one or several areas of operations critical for re-starting growth and help obtain access to market sources for new capital. The two supplementary components will enhance the impact of the core one, i.e. (i) Market Information Improvement component will provide systematic information to the market about the range and quality of domestically available consulting services; and (ii) Restructuring Promotion component. II. Restructuring Promotion Component Objectives and Rationale 1. Obiectives. As the main objective of the ERSP is to develop a sustainable capacity in the Russian private sector for market-based restructuring, the Restructuring Promotion (RP) component will strengthen the core, Restructuring Services component by familiarizing the market agents with restructuring approaches in general, and the project, in particular. Its main goals are to increase the demand for the project, to better position eligible enterprises to absorb the consulting services efficiently, as well as, possibly, trigger independent transactions between enterprises and consultants in the market place. In line

The component is also targeted to the federal and regional government agencies and local authorities to enhance their understanding of and thus create incentives for their initiating and supporting the restructuring process at the regional/local level. 2. Project Component Rationale rests on the need to enhance key market players (enterprise managers, consultants, banks, investors, government officials) understanding of the ERSP and of the restructuring process in general, including: (i) Along with the lack of financial and technical capacity to execute successful turnaround of their companies, few enterprise managers and owners are aware of the role of restructuring as the main tool of achieving financial and operational sustainability of their enterprises due to informational gaps in the market. Within the framework of the Restructuring Promotion component they will be exposed to: (I) the general description of restructuring techniques as well as to best practice examples of successful company turnarounds; (2) the comparative analysis of the availability and value of consulting services (foreign and local) in general and within the framework of the RP component; (3) the process of selection and management of external consultants; (4) the risks and benefits of using external consultant services in general; (5) awareness of financial sources/opportunities open for restructuring, including various donor-supported term- financing and investment programs. (ii)At present, local consulting market is unable to satisfy the growing needs for restructuring consulting services due to the lack of capacity and know-how. (iii)Other important players in the market (banks, investors, government agencies) who are interested in the revival of Russian enterprises as potential objects for investments, the process hindered by many economic and political factors, will be enhanced with better understanding of the role of restructuring in general as well with the knowledge of transparent support scheme available under the project which prime objective is to develop new institutional and financial relationship for the on-going market based restructuring process.

doc.abstracts: The Enterprise Restructuring Services Project will promote enterprise reform by facilitating the development of a sustainable capacity in the Russian private sector for market-based restructuring. The project has a core component enhanced by two small supplementary components: (1) Restructuring services, the main component, comprises a direct credit line of the Ministry of Finance to about 250-270 eligible private enterprises to improve their operations and to obtain new market-based financing. (2) The restructuring promotion component will reinforce the core component by soliciting demand, improving the quality of enterprise sub-projects, supporting a marketing program, and developing targeted short workshops. (3) The market information improvement component will finance the development and dissemination of a database of domestic consulting firms, which will reinforce the core component by facilitating teaming arrangements between foreign and domestic consulting firms and transfers of skills and know-how to domestic firms.
